Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: NSF INCLUDES - Changing the Face of STEM in the U.S. Virgin Islands through Targeted Interventions to Expand Opportunities and Broaden Participation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT

A non-technical description of the project test explains its significance and importance.

The goal of this project is to help students easily identify themselves as science or engineering professionals and increase the proportion of the local population, dominantly minorities, who pursue science and technology careers. Experience has demonstrated that students are most engaged in technical fields when they can participate in active, hands-on learning around problems with application to their local community. The focus of the effort is in marine science, which has local relevance to both the environment and the economy of the U.S. Virgin Islands. The project will use interventions at three crucial stages: middle school, high-school-college transition, and master-PhD transition, to engage students with specific active-learning and research-oriented programs. Community partners comprise a wide-ranging local organization that leverages the resources of other successful collaborations.

A technical description of the project

This project will create a transferable model that uses innovative partnerships among universities, governmental and non-governmental organizations, a professional society, and businesses, to create a local backbone organization with a shared vision for change and common success metrics broaden participation in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). This project addresses the critical challenge of building scientific identity to increase interest and engagement of underrepresented minorities in STEM fields in the U.S. Virgin Islands. The plan includes targeted interventions at three significant times in the student career pathway (middle/high school, early college, and graduate school) that comprise: (1) field experiences in the marine sciences for middle/high school students, (2) early field research experiences for college freshmen and sophomore students, (3) bridge programming to a Ph.D. partnership with Pennsylvania State University, and (4) an intensive mentoring program. The model is grounded in social innovation theory through a framework that meets the five conditions for collective impact: common agenda, shared measurement of data and results, mutually reinforcing activities, continuous communication, and backbone support.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goals for this project are to: 1) Create a local backbone organization that can support project initiatives; 2) Utilize intervention activities targeting individuals at known dropout points (Middle/High School, Undergraduate, Master’s) to provide support and engage students a level that leads to a pathway of success in a STEM career path; 3) Increase Virgin Islanders interest in/pursuing STEM career pathways; and 4) Build a vetted, transferable, scalable model that can be used to launch an NSF ALLIANCES project. Specifically, we aimed to recruit more male and female African American/Afro-Caribbean individuals involved with STEM at three education levels: Middle School (MS)/High School (HS), Undergraduate, Graduate: Master’s Level students. Our project focused on involving participants in geosciences. Our participants need increased exposure to STEM activities, so they can begin to imagine themselves as scientists and thus begin to develop a science identity. Our populations face many barriers to entering the STEM pipeline; one major obstacle is availability of activities relating to STEM. Students do not have many opportunities to engage with STEM activities like surveying coral reefs, using GIS mapping programs, and working in mangrove lagoons. This project provided opportunities to participate in events like these to URM students, so they have an opportunity to engage with STEM activities. 

We analyzed Bridge Program data (interviews, open-ended questionnaires, and surveys) for the perceived positive and negative aspects of the Bridge Program; we deductively coded student responses as either positive or negative. We then inductively coded coded responses into themes, then coded the themes into categories. For the Science Identity Preliminary Findings, we deductively coded student interviews based on the Carlone and Johnson Framework (2007), identifying 3 domains of science identity: recognition, performance, and competence. Recognition: the students see themselves as scientists or recognize that others see them as scientists; Performance: the students are doing things that scientists do such as social performance (science clubs and extracurricular activities) and using tools that scientists use; Competence: the students are comfortable in doing science and have the appropriate scientific content knowledge for their level of education. We coded student responses as either positive, negative, or neutral for two categories: Recognition of Self and Recognition by Others. In the framework, these two categories paired with tracking student performance can be used to identify if an individual has a science identity.

Prior to participation participant's motivations for applying and expections centered around the perceived lab techniques they would learn an the individuals (professors and graduate students) they would work with. Students were also apprehensive about their lack of experience putting them behind others in the program, and had a fear of failure. They felt a pressure at being choosen to participate and that they would not succeed during the bridge program. After participation, participants found the program to be enjoyable overall and had a better understanding of the expectations of a PhD program. They also felt that they made valuble social connections and built valuble skill sets. Additionally, they felt that some of the material was overly challenging and had to overcome the challenges associated with working in close spaces with people for long periods of time. In terms of Science Identity, we found that one student had an increase in their Recognition of Self from negative to positive. All other bridge students entered the program with a positive Recognition of Self, seven left the program with a positive Recognition of Self. Prior to the program, nine of the students reported a positive Recognition by Others (with one student also having had a negative experience with a prior mentor), of those, three reported a positive Recognition by Others after the program.

Based on our preliminary findings, Bridge Program participants started the program with a recognition of self and by others as being scientitsts and therefore did not have increases in a science identity. However, the Bridge Program was successfull at helping students prepare for a post-Master's program involving lab techniques and a PhD program. As of this date, two of the bridge program participants have been accepted into PhD programs.
